name: eutrema-japonicum
country-or-region-of-origin: South Korea, S Sakhalin to Japan
distribution: and New Zealand and China. In the United States: Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina
edibility: Wasabi rhizomes are finely grated into a green paste about the consistency of toothpaste, which produces a distinct spicy condiment similar to horseradish and hot mustard.  It is served with sushi, salads, poultry, sausage, steamed rice, soups, and a garnish for bread.  The leaves, flowers, leafstalks, and sliced rhizomes are used to make a Japanese pickle called wasabi-zuke.  Young leaves are used in salads and sandwiches. Note, eating raw leaves can cause diarrhea.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
fruit-description: The fruit is linear 1/4 to 3/4 inch long and wide, and grooved lengthwise.
flower-description: Small clusters of tiny, white, cross shaped flowers (1/4 to 1/10 of an inch) that bloom in late winter to early spring.
leaf-description: The attractive simple leaves are 3 to 6 inches long and 3 to 7 inches wide, palmately veined, toothed and divided into 3-6 leaflets. Each leaf is borne on long leaf stalks. with small leaflets in between.
uses: Wasabi is studied for medicinal uses, including as an anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and its potential to reduce osteoporosis, heart disease, and cancer.
